answers.a: E262 is sodium acetates (sodium acetate and sodium diacetate), used as a preservative and acidity regulator to control pH and inhibit microbial growth.
Sodium acetate is CH3COONa (anhydrous) or CH3COONa·3H2O (trihydrate); sodium diacetate (E262(ii)) is CH3COONa·CH3COOH.
Chemically it’s written as CH3COONa (often abbreviated NaOAc); on food labels the code is E262.
E262 isn’t an area code—it’s the EU food additive number for sodium acetates shown on ingredient lists.

answers.q: why are sodium bicarbonate and sidium acetates
answers.a: Both are sodium salts of weak acids used in foods: sodium bicarbonate acts as a leavening agent/acid neutralizer, while sodium acetates preserve foods and help regulate acidity.
